verses.text: Now these are the people of the province who came up out of the captivity, whom Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon had carried away to Babylon. They returned to Jerusalem and Judah, each to his own city.
verses.comment: This verse sets the context of return from exile, emphasizing restoration. The literal sense highlights God's faithfulness to His promises of restoration. See also parallels in Nehemiah 7.

verses.text: They came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispar, Bigvai, Rehum, and Baanah. The number of the men of the people of Israel:
verses.comment: These returning leaders foreshadow the re-establishment of the temple and ordered worship. Zerubbabel and Jeshua both prefigure leadership later fulfilled perfectly in Christ (Heb. 3:1–6).

verses.text: The sons of Parosh, two thousand one hundred and seventy-two.
verses.comment: Genealogies such as these show the continuity of God’s people from exile to restoration, reinforcing sacred tradition and lineage.

verses.text: The sons of Shephatiah, three hundred and seventy-two.
verses.comment: Meticulous records preserved faithfulness and connection to the covenant people.

verses.text: The sons of Arah, seven hundred and seventy-five.
verses.comment: Each family’s name is remembered, embodying the value God places on every member in His people (see Luke 12:7).

verses.text: The sons of Pahath-moab, of the sons of Jeshua and Joab, two thousand eight hundred and twelve.
verses.comment: The names connect to earlier priestly and royal lines (cf. Numbers 26:3), anticipating the importance of succession and order in God's people.

verses.text: The sons of Elam, one thousand two hundred and fifty-four.
verses.comment: Elam will appear again in Nehemiah’s list, confirming a faithful remnant.

verses.text: The sons of Zattu, nine hundred and forty-five.
verses.comment: Names in these lists are preserved for generations, underlining the heritage in the faith community.

verses.text: The sons of Zaccai, seven hundred and sixty.
verses.comment: The continual repetition of family lines affirms the integral importance of spiritual ancestry.

verses.text: The sons of Bani, six hundred and forty-two.
verses.comment: The return is not just individual but communitarian, reinforcing the collective nature of salvation.

verses.text: The sons of Bebai, six hundred and twenty-three.
verses.comment: Bebai’s descendants also appear in covenant signings (Neh. 10:15), showing ongoing generational faithfulness.

verses.text: The sons of Azgad, one thousand two hundred and twenty-two.
verses.comment: Azgad’s notable household further anchors the returnees’ identities in tradition.

verses.text: The sons of Adonikam, six hundred and sixty-six.
verses.comment: This number is noteworthy in apocalyptic references (Rev. 13:18), but here is simply a historical census.

verses.text: The sons of Bigvai, two thousand fifty-six.
verses.comment: Bigvai’s house shows the significant numbers committed to restoring worship in Jerusalem.

verses.text: The sons of Adin, four hundred and fifty-four.
verses.comment: Adin’s descendants are listed to attest the meticulous keeping of spiritual records.

verses.text: The sons of Ater, of Hezekiah, ninety-eight.
verses.comment: The mention of Hezekiah may recall the faithful king, highlighting the importance of spiritual leadership.

verses.text: The sons of Bezai, three hundred and twenty-three.
verses.comment: Bezai appears among those who commit to covenant renewal.

verses.text: The sons of Jorah, one hundred and twelve.
verses.comment: Attention to detail here shows integrity in restoring proper order.

verses.text: The sons of Hashum, two hundred and twenty-three.
verses.comment: Hashum’s family faithfully preserved their identity through the exile.

verses.text: The sons of Gibbar, ninety-five.
verses.comment: The preservation of small family lines points to the value of individual faithfulness.

verses.text: The men of Bethlehem, one hundred and twenty-three.
verses.comment: Bethlehem is the birthplace of David and later Jesus, connecting the returnees with messianic prophecy (Mic. 5:2).

verses.text: The men of Netophah, fifty-six.
verses.comment: Netophah’s mention points to lesser-known faithful villages tied to the worship center.

verses.text: The men of Anathoth, one hundred and twenty-eight.
verses.comment: Jeremiah came from Anathoth, evidencing continuity of prophetic ministry.

verses.text: The sons of Azmaveth, forty-two.
verses.comment: Smaller groups are honored equally in the spiritual rebuilding.

verses.text: The sons of Kiriath-arim, Chephirah, and Beeroth, seven hundred and forty-three.
verses.comment: Villages near Jerusalem demonstrate unity of larger region in worship.

verses.text: The men of Ramah and Geba, six hundred and twenty-one.
verses.comment: Geba’s priestly connection affirms the role of priestly families in spiritual renewal.

verses.text: The men of Michmas, one hundred and twenty-two.
verses.comment: Michmas later becomes a site of important events in Israel’s defense (1 Sam. 13:2).

verses.text: The men of Bethel and Ai, two hundred and twenty-three.
verses.comment: Bethel, an ancient place of worship (Gen. 28:19), is restored to sacred use.

verses.text: The sons of Nebo, fifty-two.
verses.comment: Each group’s restoration prefigures the constant need for unity in the body of the faithful.

verses.text: The sons of Magbish, one hundred and fifty-six.
verses.comment: Magbish appears only here, highlighting God’s remembrance of even obscure communities.

verses.text: The sons of the other Elam, one thousand two hundred and fifty-four.
verses.comment: Possible double listing due to family divisions, testifying care in record keeping.

verses.text: The sons of Harim, three hundred and twenty.
verses.comment: Harim is a frequent priestly family, some named among later covenant renewals.

verses.text: The sons of Lod, Hadid, and Ono, seven hundred and twenty-five.
verses.comment: Ono and Lod later provide important supplies to the temple (Neh. 11:35).

verses.text: The sons of Jericho, three hundred and forty-five.
verses.comment: Jericho, site of Israel’s first conquest, is once more included in the people’s return.

verses.text: The sons of Senaah, three thousand six hundred and thirty.
verses.comment: Senaah’s large numbers show the scale of restoration and preparation to rebuild.

verses.text: The priests: the sons of Jedaiah, of the house of Jeshua, nine hundred and seventy-three.
verses.comment: Attention is now given to priestly families. Priestly successors guarantee authentic sacraments and worship, prefiguring priesthood in the New Covenant (Heb. 7:23–24).

verses.text: The sons of Immer, one thousand and fifty-two.
verses.comment: Priesthood based on family lines anticipates apostolic succession (cf. Acts 1:20–26).

verses.text: The sons of Pashhur, one thousand two hundred and forty-seven.
verses.comment: Pashhur’s priestly line continues, with some of his descendants appearing in prophetic texts (Jer. 20:1).

verses.text: The sons of Harim, one thousand and seventeen.
verses.comment: The emphasis is again on established lines of ordained ministry.

verses.text: The Levites: the sons of Jeshua and Kadmiel, of the sons of Hodaviah, seventy-four.
verses.comment: Note the continuity of Levitical order, crucial for liturgical service and sacred music (1 Chr. 23:24–32).

verses.text: The singers: the sons of Asaph, one hundred and twenty-eight.
verses.comment: Asaph’s descendants continue the Davidic tradition of liturgical song—vital to temple worship.

verses.text: The sons of the gatekeepers: the sons of Shallum, the sons of Ater, the sons of Talmon, the sons of Akkub, the sons of Hatita, the sons of Shobai, one hundred and thirty-nine in all.
verses.comment: Gatekeepers supervised sacred spaces, foreshadowing later ministerial roles (Acts 6:2–6).

verses.text: The temple servants: the sons of Ziha, the sons of Hasupha, the sons of Tabbaoth;
verses.comment: Temple servants (Nethinim) were necessary for order and worship, showing the dignity of service in God’s house.

verses.text: The sons of Keros, the sons of Siaha, the sons of Padon,
verses.comment: Each temple servant’s name is important. All service in God’s house is honored (cf. Mark 9:41).

verses.text: The sons of Lebanah, the sons of Hagabah, the sons of Akkub,
verses.comment: The many named families foster a sense of deep-rooted tradition and unity.

verses.text: The sons of Hagab, the sons of Shalmai, the sons of Hanan,
verses.comment: Service to the Lord continues across generations, modeling spiritual stability.

verses.text: The sons of Giddel, the sons of Gahar, the sons of Reaiah,
verses.comment: The role of these servants points to the need for a cooperative spiritual community.

verses.text: The sons of Rezin, the sons of Nekoda, the sons of Gazzam,
verses.comment: Mentioning these names highlights the dignity and memory of all who serve in God’s sanctuary.

verses.text: The sons of Uzza, the sons of Paseah, the sons of Besai,
verses.comment: Preservation of every family line testifies to the spiritual inclusivity of the community.

verses.text: The sons of Asnah, the sons of Meunim, the sons of Nephisim,
verses.comment: Even lesser-known families play an indispensable part in the restoration.

verses.text: The sons of Bakbuk, the sons of Hakupha, the sons of Harhur,
verses.comment: Every act of service is remembered by the Lord.

verses.text: The sons of Bazluth, the sons of Mehida, the sons of Harsha,
verses.comment: Their work supports the higher liturgical roles, like the twelve apostles’ helpers (Luke 8:2–3).

verses.text: The sons of Barkos, the sons of Sisera, the sons of Temah,
verses.comment: The list highlights profound organization and continuity.

verses.text: The sons of Neziah, the sons of Hatipha.
verses.comment: Final group among temple servants; unity in devotion is vital for worship.

verses.text: The sons of Solomon’s servants: the sons of Sotai, the sons of Hassophereth, the sons of Peruda,
verses.comment: These servants, descendants from Solomon’s workforce, were integrated into holy service—a sign of readiness to serve God selflessly.

verses.text: The sons of Jaalah, the sons of Darkon, the sons of Giddel,
The sons of Shephatiah, the sons of Hattil, the sons of Pochereth-hazzebaim, the sons of Ami.
verses.comment: These names show the scope and variety of people united in returning to rebuild.

verses.text: All the temple servants and the sons of Solomon’s servants were three hundred and ninety-two.
verses.comment: Their shared duties demonstrate the necessity for service roles in a functioning faith community. Jesus Himself came not to be served but to serve (Mark 10:45).

verses.text: And these were the ones who came up from Tel-melah, Tel-harsha, Cherub, Addan, and Immer, but they could not prove their fathers’ houses or their ancestry, whether they belonged to Israel:
verses.comment: Purity of lineage was essential for specific ministry roles, paralleling the church’s discernment for leadership.

verses.text: The sons of Delaiah, the sons of Tobiah, the sons of Nekoda, six hundred and fifty-two.
verses.comment: Highlights the issue of rightful membership and the importance of spiritual lineage.

verses.text: And of the sons of the priests: the sons of Habaiah, the sons of Hakkoz, the sons of Barzillai (who had taken a wife from the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and was called by their name).
verses.comment: Priestly lines often had to demonstrate verifiable descent, pointing to the legitimacy of ordination and tradition (cf. Matt. 1:1–16).

verses.text: These looked for their names among those registered in the genealogies, but they were not found. Therefore they were excluded from the priesthood as unclean.
verses.comment: Proper succession is essential for legitimate ministry, and physical records mirror spiritual discernment for true shepherds.

verses.text: And the governor told them that they were not to eat of the most holy things until a priest could consult with the Urim and Thummim.
verses.comment: Shows the cautious discernment regarding the sacred. The governor’s respect for established ritual foreshadows the later practice of spiritual authority and discernment (Acts 15:1–6).

verses.text: The whole assembly together was forty-two thousand three hundred and sixty,
verses.comment: The grand total demonstrates the gathered remnant’s faithfulness and preparation for restored worship in the land.

verses.text: besides their male and female servants, of whom there were seven thousand three hundred and thirty-seven; and they had two hundred male and female singers.
verses.comment: Choirs and sacred music are emphasized, integral to ordered worship, anticipating heavenly liturgy (Rev. 5:8–9).

verses.text: Their horses were seven hundred and thirty-six, their mules two hundred and forty-five,
verses.comment: The mention of animals shows God’s provision for practical needs in holy pursuits.

verses.text: their camels four hundred and thirty-five, and their donkeys six thousand seven hundred and twenty.
verses.comment: Practical resources are given for the journey and restoration, signifying the material support for spiritual missions.

verses.text: Some of the heads of fathers’ houses, when they came to the house of the Lord that is in Jerusalem, offered freely for the house of God, to set it up in its place.
verses.comment: Free-will offerings for the temple mirror true worship: giving materially for spiritual purposes, anticipating the generosity of the Magi and early believers.

verses.text: They gave according to their ability to the treasury of the work sixty-one thousand darics of gold, five thousand minas of silver, and one hundred priests’ garments.
verses.comment: The ordered giving demonstrates both charity and the support of sacred office—priests’ garments recall preparation for sacrifice (Ex. 28:2–4).

verses.text: So the priests, the Levites, some of the people, the singers, the gatekeepers, and the temple servants lived in their towns, and all Israel in their towns.
verses.comment: Restoration is complete when all members—all roles and gifts—are in place and settled. This anticipates the ordered, united people of God in the new covenant community (Eph. 2:19–22).
